ygData.subject: Re: [cantera] Install Cantera on Mac OS X
ygData.msgSnippet: This can happen if your system has 2 different Python installations. Mac OS X comes with a version of Python in /usr/bin. But since it usually not the latest

Subject: Re: [cantera] Install Cantera on Mac OS X
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=44728387; y=_p1b4rBdnJRiERCy0SkPWobr2a-tJgw6NpTvVv_QWRMy
X-Yahoo-Profile: dggoodwin

This can happen if your system has 2 different Python installations.   
Mac OS X comes with a version of Python in /usr/bin. But since it  
usually not the latest version, many people install their own Python  
(for example, MacPython, which comes with many extras not in the  
system Python, including the IDLE editor.  You need to make sure that  
you install Cantera for the particular Python interpreter you later  
want to use Cantera with.  The system Python from Apple and MacPython  
store their files in completely different places.  In particular,  
they do not share the same "site-packages" directory, so packages  
installed for one won't be seen by the other one.

My recommendation is to not mess with the system Python in /usr/bin.   
The OS uses this for various tasks, and it is best to leave it  
alone.  So install MacPython or some other version for your use with  
Cantera.  All you have to do to tell Cantera which one to use is to  
define environment variable PYTHON_CMD to point to the desired Python  
interpreter.  For example, if your Python interpreter is in /usr/ 
local/bin, then you would set this as follows:

PYTHON_CMD=/usr/local/bin/python
export PYTHON_CMD

This syntax is for the "sh" shell; if you are using csh, then the  
syntax is a bit different.   You can define this in the preconfig  
script, and then it will be added to your "setup_cantera" script.  If  
you then add the line "source setup_cantera" to your shell  
initialization script (for example, .bashrc), then this will happen  
automatically and you won't have to think about it anymore...

Dave
